content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. There's just so much stress at work, and I can't stop worrying about getting fired. It keeps me up at night, and I just don't know how to deal with it.

That sounds really overwhelming, dealing with work stress and the worry about your job while also struggling with sleep. It must be exhausting to go through this every day and night. How have you been feeling about all of it lately?

Honestly, I feel drained all the time. During the day, I try to push through, but at night I can’t shut my brain off. It feels like a cycle I can’t escape, and I’m constantly worried I’m going to let my family down.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot right now, trying to manage work stress, lack of sleep, and the weight of feeling responsible for your family. That’s a lot to handle all at once. What do you think makes things feel even harder for you in those moments when your mind won’t stop racing?

I think it’s just all the thoughts about work piling up together—worrying about layoffs, thinking about what I might’ve done wrong, and then imagining worst-case scenarios. I end up grabbing my phone to distract myself, but then I’m scrolling for hours, and it makes everything worse. It’s like I know I shouldn’t, but I just can’t stop.

It must feel frustrating to realize that scrolling makes things worse yet still feel stuck in the habit when your mind is racing. You're juggling so many worries, and it sounds like you're trying to find some relief, even if it isn't helping the way you hoped. What do you think helps, even in small ways, when you're feeling this overwhelmed?

Honestly, nothing seems to really help right now. I’ve tried just lying there or putting the phone down, but then my thoughts just feel even louder. It feels like I’m stuck in this loop where no matter what I do, I can’t quiet my mind.

That feeling of being stuck in a loop must be really difficult, especially when you’ve already tried things to calm yourself but the thoughts seem to get louder. It shows how much you care and want to find a way out of this cycle, even though it feels so challenging right now. What would be most helpful to you, if things could change?

I think just being able to fall asleep easily and wake up without this constant weight on my chest would make a huge difference. I just want to have the energy to be there for my family and not feel like I’m barely keeping it together all the time.

That sounds like it’s so important to you—being able to sleep well and wake up feeling lighter so you can be more present and supportive for your family. You’re clearly invested in wanting things to get better, even while you’re feeling drained right now. What steps do you think might move you closer to feeling like that?

I don’t really know where to start, to be honest. I guess trying to put my phone down at night would be a place to begin, but it’s hard when I feel like it’s the only thing keeping me distracted from all the overthinking. I just don’t know if anything will actually help.

It makes sense that putting your phone down feels like both a step forward and a challenge at the same time, especially when it’s been your go-to distraction from all the overwhelming thoughts. What do you think would help make that change feel less intimidating? Even a small step that doesn’t feel too hard to try right now?

Maybe I could try setting a timer or limit for being on my phone at night, like cutting it off after a certain time, but I’m not sure if I’ll actually stick to it. It’s just hard when those thoughts won’t leave me alone, you know?

That’s a thoughtful idea—setting a limit might give you more control over the phone use and your evenings. It’s understandable to worry about sticking to it, especially when the thoughts feel relentless. You’re being honest about the challenge, but also exploring steps forward, which is a strong start. How can you make trying this feel manageable for yourself, even if the thoughts persist?

Maybe I could start small, like cutting back just 10 or 15 minutes at first instead of trying to completely stop all at once. I feel like that might be easier to handle, and I could see how it goes from there. I guess it’s worth a try.

Starting small, with just 10 or 15 minutes, sounds like a practical and achievable way to ease into the change without overwhelming yourself. You’re giving yourself a chance to see how it feels and build on it gradually. Would you like to explore anything else before thinking more about steps like this?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
